body: `checkGlobals`, called by `recalcMeta`, cleans out these entries. So wherever they come from is relatively recent, as that check is done once a month...
Spotted it: It's `checkGlobals` itself that can introduce 0-length global versions. PR incoming.

issue.title: lib/db: Remove emptied global list in checkGlobals (fixes #6425)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
If `checkGlobal` cleans out all entries in a global list entry (e.g. when it has only one entry pointing at nothing), it then commits that empty global list into the db. It's obviously not guaranteed to be the cause of #6425, but I can't find any way an empty list is committed in the other places we modify the global lists and adding check panics for empty global version lists and running integration tests didn't surface anything either - still no guarantee, but good enough imo.

~~Unfortunately I can't think of a good way to trigger `checkGlobals` on upgrade without a db schema upgrade, so the upgrade won't fix this immediately - ideas welcome.~~
See #6429 for a one-time check.

While checking everything I also found and removed two instances of useless code (`insertedAt` is never -1, we always insert the file).

body: I marked it with skip-changelog, as previously we just ignored it, which in the failure mode I fixed in #6426 is a working strategy.

issue.title: lib/db, lib/syncthing: Repair db once on upgrade (ref #6425, #6427)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Both #6425 and #6427 require a metadata (respectively sequence) recalc. This adds an exported method to `db.Lowlevel` to trigger that, which is then done on startup if an upgrade with a previous version <1.4.2 is detected.

I moved the code for the recalculation from set.go to lowlevel.go and made them methods of `*Lowlevel` (which before got passed as arg). This is entirely copy&paste, except that the previous `recalc` fixture now is now a method called `getMetaAndCheck`.

I manually tested running a binary from this PR on a db from 1.4.0.
